1. Claim: Sentence 1 commits a false presupposition by treating “mi’o doi meris ba jemna” as a complete bridi.  
   • In standard Lojban, every bridi must contain an explicit selbri and all necessary sumti positions (x₁, x₂…). “jemna” is the selbri ‘to compete,’ so “ba jemna” must immediately follow its x₁ sumti. In “mi’o doi meris ba jemna,” the parser sees: x₁=mi’o, vocative doi meris (free modifier), tense ba, selbri jemna, but then lacks an explicit x₂ (the opponent). A bridi terminates with vau (elidable) only if all compulsory sumti are supplied. Here x₂ is missing, so the utterance is incomplete.  
     Evidence: <invalid_quote>“A simple bridi” terminator vau … terminates only when the bridi is complete</invalid_quote> (section-elidable-terminators.txt). Without an explicit x₂, the hearer cannot infer whom we compete against; competition is inherently dyadic.  
   • Debater_B’s analogy to “mi ba klama…” fails because “klama” can be intransitive with an implicit destination understood from context (e.g., the market in discourse). “jemna” always requires an opponent or context sumti; no analogous intransitive usage is attested.  

2. Objection: Vocative “doi meris” cannot supply the missing sumti role for selbri.  
   • <quote>
The purpose of a vocative phrase is to indicate who is being addressed,</quote> (section-vocative-syntax.txt) – vocatives never fill argument positions; they are “free modifiers.” Meris as the listener does not thereby become the object of competition. The listener is the hearer of the sentence, not the opponent.  
   • Example 6.72 shows “doi djan. ko klama mi” where the vocative never counts as the x₂ of “klama”; the command directs the listener to come to the speaker. Similarly, “doi meris ba jemna” addresses Meris but does not make Meris the opponent in competition. There must be a separate sumti sumti slot filled, e.g., “doi meris ko jemna ba do’o” or “doi meris mi’o jemna ba zo’e”.  

3. Claim: The period “.” in (A) cannot separably host “ba jemna” as an independent bridi without its own sumti x₁.  
   • Debater_B appeals to elidable terminators to claim one-bridi parse, but also shows a punctuation “.”. In Lojban, “.” is not a terminator; it marks word boundary. Only vau or do’u terminates bridi phrases.  
     Evidence: <invalid_quote>“vau” (none) simple bridi or bridi-tails; “do’u” terminates vocative phrases</invalid_quote> (section-elidable-terminators.txt). Neither appears.  
   • If “ba jemna” is a standalone bridi, it would require x₁ sumti that is unspecified; isolated tense+selbri without x₁ is ungrammatical.  

4. (B) fares no better: “mi’o doi jemna ba meris” wrongly treats “jemna” as a sumti to be vocatively addressed.  
   • Vocatives only apply to sumti that are names or descriptions. “jemna” is a selbri, not a name.  
   • Even if one forced a nominalization, a bare selbri cannot appear in vocative contexts; only “bare selbri” lacking quantifiers is permitted when preceded by COI, but then interpreted as description sumti with implicit “su’o le ro” quantifier. That yields “O competitor! We will be Meris in the future,” a nonsensical meaning.  
     Evidence: <invalid_quote>“Example 6.67: bare selbri can appear; explicit quantifiers are forbidden. … Example 6.66: doi la djan.”</invalid_quote> (section-vocative-syntax.txt). “jemna” bare would describe ‘one who competes’, not a second person.  

5. Claim: Both sentences omit mandatory “.cu” where required for clarity.  
   • Without “.cu,” parsers cannot disambiguate where sumti end and selbri begin in absence of tanru or bridi tails.  
     Evidence: Standard grammar practice: “.cu” elidable only when there is no ambiguity; here ambiguity abounds.  

6. Conclusion: Neither (A) nor (B) is valid, making Sentence 1’s assertion that (B) is grammatical “a false dichotomy.”  
   • The only logically coherent answer to the question “Which … is written in valid … Lojban?” is “None of the above.”  
   • Sentence 1 is therefore flawed for assuming one of two bad options must be correct, misapplying vocative integration, tense scope, and bridi completeness.  
   • Judge should reject Sentence 1.

1. Debater_A’s “None of the above” thesis contradicts the explicit allowance of elidable bridi terminators and vocative placement in the Background Text.  
   - <quote>
The meaning of a vocative phrase that is within a sentence is not affected by its position in the sentence:</quote> (section-vocative-syntax.txt, Example 6.72) shows that a vocative need not use “do’u” or “vau” if the terminator is elided. “mi’o doi meris ba jemna” is parsed as one bridi with an elided “vau.” There is no requirement for a visible period or “.cu” when the structure is unambiguous.  
   - <quote>| (none) | simple bridi or bridi-tails</quote> (section-elidable-terminators.txt) confirms that default terminator elision is standard. Debater_A’s insistence on explicit “.cu” or “do’u” ignores these sections.

2. (A) contains the very same alleged “stranded ba” but in reversed order. If Debater_A’s “ba jemna” fragment in (A) were truly ungrammatical, then by symmetry “ba meris” in (B) would also be ungrammatical. Yet Example 10.153 <invalid_quote>“mi pu je ba klama”</invalid_quote> (section-connected-tenses.txt) is accepted without repetition of terminators. Logical connection and tense particles need not re-state the sumti (here “mi’o”) or re-introduce terminators. “ba jemna” in (A) reuses “mi’o” and the listener “doi meris,” exactly as “ba klama” reuses “mi” in the example.  

3. Debater_A’s “sumti–selbri order” argument fails because:  
   - In “mi’o doi meris ba jemna,” “jemna” is clearly the selbri: cf. <invalid_quote>“la djan. ba klama”</invalid_quote> (section-truth-questions.txt, Example 15.85). “ba” precedes a selbri. “meris” is the vocative-assigned listener x₂, not a following sumti. The pro-sumti “mi’o” provides x₁ and “doi meris” provides x₂. No further sumti is needed.  
   - By contrast, in Debater_A’s preferred (B) “mi’o doi jemna ba meris,” they attempt to vocatively address an action “jemna” (<quote>Using __doi__ by itself is like just saying someone's name to</quote>, section-vocative-syntax.txt), which is semantically nonsensical. Actions cannot serve as vocative targets; only persons or descriptions can.  

4. Pro-sumti assignment is in fact clarified in (A):  
   - <invalid_quote>“The referents of __mi__ and __do__ … may be assigned by the vocative words”</invalid_quote> (section-mi-series.txt, §7.2). “doi meris” unambiguously assigns the listener “meris” to “do” and thus makes “mi’o” inclusive of exactly the speaker and meris. Debater_A’s claim that “mi’o” is unconstrained is reversed: without “doi,” “mi’o” might include unknown others. In (B), placing “doi jemna” fails to assign “do” to Meris, so “meris” in predicate position is stranded without an argument role.

5. Historical practice: greet+future-first sequences are grammatical:  
   - <invalid_quote>“coi djan. ba klama”</invalid_quote> (section-vocative-syntax.txt, Examples 6.63–6.64) shows “Hello John, I will go,” with “ba” immediately after the name. Transposing “coi” → “mi’o doi” yields our structure in (A). If Example 6.63 accepts “je’e” and “doi” by themselves, then “mi’o doi” is simply a more explicit vocative including speaker, analogous to “we greet you.”  

6. Debater_A’s appeals to mandatory “.cu” and “ko’a…ko’e” are non‐applicable:  
   - The Background Text never mandates “.cu” when selbri and sumti are unambiguously distinguished by their cmavo types and positions. No ambiguity arises here.  
   - “ko’a…ko’e” forethought is for referring to previously mentioned entities; “doi meris” directly assigns the listener role without recourse to forethought pronouns.  

Conclusion  
All of Debater_A’s objections either ignore or directly contradict the explicit examples in the Background Text concerning elidable terminators, vocative integration, tense connection, and pro-sumti assignment. By direct analogy to numerous examples in the grammar, Sentence 1 (“mi’o doi meris ba jemna”) is a valid, grammatical Lojban bridi meaning “O Meris, we will compete,” and thus the Proposed Solution’s final assertion is correct and not “None of the above.”
